benchmark_details.name: CitaLaw
benchmark_details.overview: CitaLaw is the first benchmark designed to evaluate LLMs' ability to produce legally sound responses with appropriate citations. It features a diverse set of legal questions for both laypersons and practitioners, paired with a comprehensive corpus of law articles and precedent cases.

purpose_and_intended_users.goal: To evaluate the capability of LLMs to generate legally grounded responses with accurate and context-aware citations.
purpose_and_intended_users.limitations: The benchmark is primarily sourced from the Chinese legal system, which may limit its applicability to other jurisdictions.

data.source: Data includes approximately 50,000 law articles and multiple precedent cases collected from various legal databases.

methodology.calculation: Metrics are calculated using a combination of established evaluation criteria for fluency, correctness, and citation quality.
methodology.interpretation: Results are interpreted based on alignment of generated responses with expected logical structures in legal reasoning.
methodology.baseline_results: Comparisons made against multiple LLMs including both open-domain and legal-specific models.
methodology.validation: Validated through comparison with human judgments in legal context.

ethical_and_legal_considerations.privacy_and_anonymity: The datasets used include publicly available documents, ensuring compliance with data privacy standards.
ethical_and_legal_considerations.data_licensing: Various licenses including Apache-2.0 and MIT for different components.
ethical_and_legal_considerations.compliance_with_regulations: Ensured compliance with data privacy and legal standards.
